A Type I error is the rejection of the null hypothesis when it is actually true, while a
Type II error is the failure to reject the null hypothesis when it is actually false.
The significance level can be interpreted as the probability that a test statistic will reject
the null hypothesis by chance when it is actually true (i.e., the probability of a Type I
error). A significance level must be specified to select the critical values for the test.
LOS 12.d
Hypothesis testing compares a computed test statistic to a critical value at a stated level
of significance, which is the decision rule for the test.
